title: Work Experience
text:
Colorado State University Soil Innovation Lab
Soil Research Laboratory Technician
Fort Collins, CO
May 2022-Present

I work at Colorado State University’s Soil Innovation Lab under Dr. Francesca Cotrufo and Dr. Paige Stanley. The Soil Innovation Lab collaborates on research of soil from all around the world to better understand the health and function of soils.

I am working on a large project researching how grazing management impacts soil health and soil carbon sequestration on rangeland and pastures. The project is called the Metrics, Management, & Monitoring (3M) project and is being led by Colorado State University, Noble Research Institute, and Michigan State University with other collaborators across the United States as well as in the United Kingdom.

Assist on a rangeland/ pasture soil health and carbon sequestration study by processing thousands of soil samples, including sieving and biogeochemical tests
Accurately record data on spreadsheets and entering data into Excel spreadsheets
Coordinating and managing a large team of fellow lab assistant to keep a large research project running efficiently and smoothly
Maintaining a clean and organized lab space
Training 2-8 lab assistants on proper laboratory protocols and procedures
Assist with troubleshooting and coming up with practical solutions



For more information, visit this website: https://www.noble.org/research/3m/





3M Project Cover








Soil Sampling in Wyoming with Dr. Francesca Cotrufo








Transplanting Seedlings to put in a Carbon Isotope Labeling Chamber




Colorado State University San Luis Valley Research Center
Grazing Management Intern
Center, CO
May 2023- August 2023

I interned at the CSU San Luis Valley Research Center on a grazing management project during the summer of 2023. The San Luis Valley is a high altitude region in southern Colorado that specializes in agriculture, but faces a limited water supply. Because of this, farmers in the valley are exploring different ways they can use their land when it’s not planted with cash crops. Integrating livestock onto cropland not actively growing cash crops is a practice being proposed, but comes with challenges producers normally specialize in either farming or ranching. I helped conduct a study on high density, rotational grazing with a small herd of goats to see if this form of management is economically and environmentally sustainable as well as practical to implement. I also worked with the director of the local CSU Extension, Larry Brown, to help create a way for producers to exchange goods and services, such as grazing land and animals that need land to graze on.

Interned with the San Luis Valley Research Center and Extension office to conduct a high density rotational grazing study
Managed a small herd of goats, including daily rotations of their pen, proper husbandry, medical care, and nutrition
Conducted and economic analysis to compare cost of forage and supplies to the benefits gained from high density rotational grazing
Collaborated with the local CSU Extension director to communicate with local producers to create a network/ list in order to connect producers who want to exchange goods and/ or services
Assisted with daily farm management tasks, such as operating a forklift, weeding fields, planting research plots, turn irrigation on and off, collect potato pollen for the breeding research team, and rogue diseased potato plants
Created a research poster to present my experience and results with stakeholders from Colorado State University and other companies







Two of the goats in my herd








Flowering potato plants. The CSU SLVRC is also a potato breeding farm








Three calfs on the farm




This is the poster I created to summarize my internship experience at the research center:



I conducted this research with help from Zach Czarnecki, Jeff Davidson, Larry Brown, and Dr. Megan Machmuller


Cambridge Animal Hospital
Veterinary Technician Assistant
Longmont, CO
June 2020- May 2022

I worked at a domestic (dog and cat only) veterinary hospital that had a high flow of surgeries and patient appointments.

Assisted other vet techs and veterinarians with performing medical procedures and prepare samples to effectively keep a faced paced hospital running smoothly and safely
Sterilized, wrapped, and sorted surgical instruments, cleaned cages, and exam rooms in order to keep a sanitary and organized hospital
Talked with owners and assisted with taking care of patients staying in the hospital











Broomfield Veterinary Hospital
Kennel Technician
Broomfield, CO
May 2017- May 2021

I worked at an exotic (cats, dogs, rabbits, birds, reptiles, amphibians, etc.) veterinary hospital that had many surgeries and clients on a daily basis. I helped lead a small team of other kennel technicians clean and stock the hospital.

Stocked medical supplies, cleaned cages and the clinic
Assisted veterinarian technicians and vets with holding rabbits for medical procedures
Took care of client’s birds being boarded in the hospital
Centrifuged blood samples and made sure all samples got sent to the lab
Cleaned and sanitized medical instruments
Led a team of other kennel technicians in order to keep an efficient and well organized team that kept the clinic clean and running smoothly
Trained new kennel technicians on proper procedure and cleaning protocol















Rocky Mountain House Rabbit Rescue
Volunteer, member of the medical team
Broomfield, CO
July 2011- February 2022

Rocky Mountain House Rabbit Rescue, formerly known as Colorado House Rabbit Society, is a shelter in Colorado dedicated exclusively to rescuing and rehabbing house rabbits. I volunteered at the shelter for 11 years doing any and all tasks needing to be done at the shelter.

Cleaned rabbit cages,
Fed and groomed rabbits
Provided medical care to rabbits

administer eye drops, fluids, injections, oral medications, etc.

Work closely with other volunteers, supervisors, and directors to help keep the rabbits healthy and happy
Educate visitors and assist during events at the shelter

title: Career Ambitions
text:
I am currently pursuing a professional science master’s in Ecosystem Science and Sustainability with a certificate in Carbon Management through the Warner College of Natural Resources at Colorado State University. During my time at CSU I will be networking with professionals and attending conferences to gain more knowledge about the field of sustainability, agriculture, and greenhouse gas management.






I am interested in working in industry, academia, government, or non-profit sectors​.
I enjoy working on large projects​ with many moving parts that have the potential to make an impact on people and the environment.
I am interested in nature-based climate solutions​ because I believe that we can work with nature, instead of against it, in order to make a better world for people and the environment.
I enjoy collaborating with multiple disciplines such as engineering, social science, environmental science, etc.
I hope to get a job where I can be on a team that works on sustainability. I know I enjoy working on projects that have many moving parts so that I can have multiple responsibilities. I also enjoy working with people and being in a role where I can help organize projects and help team members. 
After learning about agrivoltaics and volunteering a day at an agrivoltaic farm, I have a growing interest in these operations.

Agrivoltaics is the practice of combining agriculture with generating energy with solar panels







Many different plants and crops growing between solar panels








Sheep on the farm graze underneath the solar panels








Solar panels on the farm can tilt to capture sunlight as the sun moves
